From Provider: Hi Person3, Sorry to hear this is happening. It can be a common side effect of the Taxol. You could soak your toes in a mixture of warm water and vinegar or warm water and peroxide several times a day, keep them dry at other times. Yes, please let Dr Person1 take a look tomorrow. Sincerely, Person2

From Provider: Atypical means that cells are not normal but not completely abnormal either - the way Dr Person1 explained it, there is a spectrum of cells where typical and atypical cells are - so atypical cells can be anywhere on that spectrum past typical. Best thing to do is follow up with ENT, which you are doing. They will keep a clo se eye on it and monitor for changes. Unclear right now to know exactly what it is since the path didn't state cancer directly. Dr Person1 wants you to know that you are doing great! I will keep an eye out for the CT neck results and have Dr Person1 review. Person2

From Patient: Hello Dr. Person1, It has been 2 years since my neck surgery and I am still having issues with my eyelid drooping and the pupil not dilating. You had thought that the surgical clamp may have caused pressure on the nerve sheath and that this would resolve itself and eventually return to normal. Should I still expect that to be the case or would surgery to address the drooping lid be a better option? Appreciate your advice. Thank you, Person2

From Provider: Hi Person1, I am sorry to hear that this has not recovered. By this point, after two years, it the nerve has not recovered then I think it is unlikely that it will resolve. It is appropriate to consider surgery for the eyelid at this point. I am available to discuss further if you would like. This type of surgery usually has the best results when done by an oculoplastic surgeon and I can make suggestions if that would be helpful. Person2

From Provider: Hi Person1, There is always the potential for further nerve recovery, but its also something that we cannot count on at this point. This problem is not a usual risk with this surgery, but in your case the tumor extended behind some of the blood vessels in the neck and was pushing on this nerve. Removing the tumor re quiring pushing on the nerve some to get the tumor out. I will put in a referral for you to see an occuloplastic surgeon. Person2

From Provider: Hi Person1, Yes, your memory is absolutely correct. The side effects generally are temporary. I can't say 100% true, but in the vast majority of cases, the side effects resolve after stopping the medication. If we run into side ef fects that affect your quality of life and you don't want to continue, we can stop at any time. Most of the side effects can be managed by holding the medications or by some supportive care (like taking anti-nausea pills prior to taking the meds to prevent nausea or taking a anti-diarrhea med if having diarrhea). If there are specifics, we can reach out to you to discuss if that's easier. Best, Person2
From Patient: Side effects sound scary. Am I remembering correctly, you told me sides effects are not permanent and would clear up after I stopped taking dabrafenib/trametinib?

From Patient: Another question , you wrote "It is still unclear whether adjuvant immune therapy vs treatment at relapse makes any difference in survival, as thus far, there have been no survival advantage to anti-PD-1 adjuvant therapy" does this apply to adjuvant therapy vs treatment at relapse with dabrafenib/trametinib? Thanks

From Provider: Hi Person1, That is in reference to anti-PD-1 therapy (so drugs like nivolumab or pembrolizumab) in the adjuvant setting (meaning after surgery). It does not apply to dabrafenib/trametinib, as these are targeted therapies specifical ly for the BRAF mutation. Treatment with dabrafenib/trametinib seem to work better in the adjuvant setting and less well in the metastatic setting. D abrafenib/trametinib decreases the recurrence risk by half and looks to improve survival in melanoma patients who have already undergone surgery. Hope that helps. Best, Person2
From Patient: Yes, Thank you

From Provider: Wow. I'm sorry to hear that and thanks for bringing it to my attention. I think it is worth pointing out that you began the zytiga in MM/DD/YYYY and I have labs from MM/DD/YYYY through MM/DD/YYYY in which the glucose was in the low 100s. I think it is likely that starting the leuprolide/zytiga/prednisone contributed to the high gluc ose level but I doubt that was the primary cause. Having blood sugars in that range is a very rare side effect of these medications though it can happen. That said, I should discuss this in more detail with the folks at the diabetes center at Org2. We should strategize about how to proceed. I will reach out to them this week. Best, Person1
